importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date marks the day of a drone attack on Khartoum international airport, just before its long-awaited reopening, raising concerns about security and stability in Sudan.
The start of the conflict between the Sudanese army and the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) in April 2023 led to the closure of Khartoum airport and widespread destruction of infrastructure.
The day before the drone attack, Sudan’s Civil Aviation Authority announced the gradual resumption of domestic flights, highlighting the significance of the airport’s reopening schedule.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Drone attacks on Khartoum have occurred over the past seven days, with the most recent attack on October 21, indicating a sustained pattern of aerial attacks by the RSF.

keyTakeAways: Khartoum international airport was targeted by a series of drone attacks on October 21, 2025, just one day before its planned reopening after over two years of closure.
The attacks, reported to include suicide drones, occurred between 4am and 6am near the airport and were allegedly carried out by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF).
No group has claimed responsibility, but the RSF has been repeatedly accused of targeting military and civilian infrastructure using drones.
The Sudanese military reportedly intercepted some drones and shot down several, but the attacks underscore ongoing insecurity despite the army’s recapture of Khartoum.
This is the third drone attack on the capital in seven days, following previous attacks on army bases in northwest Khartoum.
Large parts of Khartoum remain in ruins, with frequent blackouts linked to RSF drone activity, impacting civilian life and recovery efforts.
The RSF continues to surround el-Fasher in Darfur, threatening to extend their control to the entire region, raising UN warnings of ethnic violence and humanitarian disaster.
The wider Sudan war has killed tens of thousands, displaced over 12 million people, and created the world’s largest displacement and hunger crises.

namedEntities.name: Khartoum international airport
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A key transportation and economic hub in Sudan, located in the capital city, which has been closed since April 2023 due to conflict and drone attacks.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The airport’s proximity to drone attacks and its planned reopening make it central to the article’s narrative about security, recovery, and national stability.

namedEntities.name: Rapid Support Forces (RSF)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A paramilitary group that has been engaged in prolonged conflict with the Sudanese army, accused of launching drone attacks and targeting infrastructure.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The RSF is directly implicated in the drone attacks on Khartoum, especially near the airport, and is a central actor in the ongoing conflict and humanitarian crisis.

namedEntities.name: Sudanese army
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The state-backed military force that recaptured Khartoum in 2023 and currently controls central and northern Sudan.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The army is in conflict with the RSF and has responded to drone attacks by shooting down some drones, signaling military resistance to ongoing attacks.

namedEntities.name: Omdurman
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The second-largest city in Sudan, located north of Khartoum and home to key military installations.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Omdurman was also hit during the drone attacks, highlighting the broader threat to military and civilian infrastructure beyond Khartoum.

namedEntities.name: el-Fasher
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The last major city in Darfur not under RSF control, currently surrounded by RSF forces.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The RSF’s efforts to seize el-Fasher could lead to control over all of Darfur and much of southern Sudan, escalating ethnic violence and regional instability.

namedEntities.name: Sudan Civil Aviation Authority
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The national body responsible for aviation operations in Sudan.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It announced the gradual resumption of domestic flights after technical preparations, making the airport’s reopening a key point of public and international interest.

namedEntities.name: United Nations
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An international organization monitoring human rights and security in Sudan.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The UN has issued warnings about potential large-scale ethnic attacks in Darfur if RSF succeeds in capturing el-Fasher, emphasizing the global humanitarian implications.

namedEntities.name: AFP (Agence France-Presse)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A global news agency that reported on the drone attacks and eyewitness accounts.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: AFP provided credible international reporting that helped disseminate information about the attacks and their significance to the global audience.

namedEntities.name: Sudan Tribune
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Paris-based Sudanese media outlet that reported on the drone attacks and cited security sources.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Sudan Tribune contributed to the verification and spread of information about drone activity and military responses.

namedEntities.name: Rakoba News
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Sudanese media source that reported on over eight drone blasts at the airport and attributed them to suicide drones.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Rakoba News provided local witness-based reporting that added credibility and detail to the account of the attacks.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A series of drone attacks, including suicide drone strikes, targeted Khartoum international airport on October 21, 2025, just one day before its long-awaited reopening after over two years of closure. The attacks, which involved more than eight blasts and were attributed to the Rapid Support Forces (RSF), raised serious concerns about security and the viability of the airport’s reopening. Despite the Sudanese military shooting down some drones, no group has claimed responsibility, and details on casualties or damage remain unavailable. The RSF has been repeatedly accused of targeting both military and civilian infrastructure, with similar attacks occurring in previous days. The conflict, which began in April 2023, has devastated Khartoum and left large areas in ruins, with frequent blackouts linked to drone activity. Meanwhile, the RSF continues to surround el-Fasher in Darfur, raising UN warnings of ethnic violence and humanitarian disaster. The wider war has killed tens of thousands, displaced over 12 million people, and created the world’s largest displacement and hunger crises.
title: Drone attack in Sudan threatens Khartoum airport’s reopening: Reports
